title: Aberporth to Mwnt Coastal Path Walking Route

images.title: Cliffs and coastal scenery by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cliffs and coastal scenery

images.title: Zorba the Geek / Edge of MoD Aberporth
images.caption: Edge of MoD Aberporth. This is the edge of the rocky promontory that blocks the progress along the coast of the Ceredigion Coast Path, which has to detour inland from this point

images.title: Pen Peles - rocks and cliffs below the Coastal Path by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Chris Gunns / Looking east from Foel y Mwnt
images.caption: Looking east from Foel y Mwnt

images.title: Deborah Tilley / Atop Foel y Mwnt
images.caption: Atop Foel y Mwnt. A great vantage point for sea gazing.

images.title: Bob Jones / Cliffs behind Mwnt Beach
images.caption: Cliffs behind Mwnt Beach. These sand-topped cliffs are unstable and dangerous. Steps have been provided by the National Trust at the beach's southern end.

images.title: Bob Jones / Mwnt Beach
images.caption: Mwnt Beach. Black cliffs line the southern side of Traeth y Mwnt (Mwnt Beach).

description: Follow the Ceredigion Coast Path from Aberporth to Mwnt on this splendid coastal walk. The walk starts in Aberporth where you pick up the waymarked footpath and follow it west past the Government MOD site to Mwnt. The area is run by the National Trust and includes a stunning secluded bay with a sandy beach. It's a great for a peaceful stroll and for spotting sea life such as dolphins and seals. The route runs for just under 5 miles with some moderate climb on the cliff top paths along the way. Towards the end of the walk you will pass Foel y Mwnt where you can enjoy wonderful views over Cardigan Bay from the hill top location. At the beach you'll also find some splendid geological cliff formations which make a great photograph. You can extend the walk by continuing along the coastal path to nearby Cardigan where there are some lovely trails along the Teifi Estuary to the 13th century castle ruins at Cilgerran .

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The Aberporth Coastal Walk will take you in the other direction to the lovely Tresaith and Penbryn Beaches. Near here you can also visit Llangrannog where you'll find a blue flag beach and a wonderful headland area with fine views over the bay. There's also an elevated hill fort and views of the River Hawen's waterfall in the village centre. In the village you can pick up the Llangrannog to Cwmtydu Walk and continue north to the beautiful secluded cove at Cwmtydu. The beach is a great place to look out for seals during September and October.

display_address: Heol y Graig, Aberporth, Ceredigion, Cymru / Wales, SA43 2HG, United Kingdom
